# The Dragon's Crown: A Tale of Fire and Destiny

## Part One: The Awakening

The village of Thornwick had stood at the edge of the Whispering Forest for three hundred years, its people living simple lives of farming, trading, and telling stories by firelight. But on the morning of the autumn equinox, when young Aria Stormwind turned sixteen, everything changed.

Aria woke to the sound of her grandmother's voice, urgent and frightened—a tone she'd never heard from the old woman before. "Aria! Come quickly, child! The mark has appeared!"

Stumbling from her bed in the small loft above the bakery her family had run for generations, Aria descended the wooden ladder to find her grandmother, Elara, standing by the window with tears streaming down her weathered face. But these weren't tears of sorrow—they were tears of wonder, fear, and something else Aria couldn't quite name.

"What mark, Grandmother? What's wrong?"

Elara turned to her, and in the morning light streaming through the window, she pointed at Aria's left shoulder. "Look, child. Look and see what destiny has written upon you."

Aria rushed to the small mirror by the washbasin, pulling aside her nightgown. There, glowing with a faint silver light, was a mark she'd never seen before—an intricate design of a dragon with its wings spread wide, its tail curling into ancient runes she couldn't read. The mark seemed to pulse with its own heartbeat, warm against her skin.

"What... what is this?" Aria breathed, touching the mark gently. A surge of energy rushed through her body, making her gasp.

Elara moved closer, her hands trembling as she reached out but didn't quite touch the mark. "It is the Dragon's Calling," she whispered. "I had hoped... I had prayed it would skip your generation. But the dragons have chosen you, Aria. You are to be a Rider."

"A Rider? Grandmother, dragons are just stories. Tales to frighten children and entertain travelers in the tavern."

"No, child." Elara's voice was firm now, taking on the tone she used when imparting her most important lessons. "Dragons are very real. They sleep, hidden in the deep places of the world, waiting for the time when they're needed again. And when that time comes, they call to those with the gift—those who can bond with them, fly with them, fight alongside them."

Aria's mind reeled. "But why me? I'm just a baker's granddaughter. I've never held a sword, never cast a spell, never done anything remarkable!"

"The dragons don't choose based on what you've done, but on what you will do. On who you are in your heart." Elara moved to a chest in the corner of the room, one Aria had seen her whole life but never been allowed to open. The old woman produced an iron key from a chain around her neck and unlocked it. From within, she drew out a rolled parchment sealed with red wax and a small leather bag that clinked with the sound of coins.

"Your grandfather was a Dragon Rider," Elara said, turning back to face Aria. "He bonded with a magnificent bronze dragon named Solarius. Together, they fought in the War of Shadows fifty years ago, when the Dark Sorcerer Malachar tried to conquer all the free kingdoms. They won, but at a terrible cost. Your grandfather was killed in the final battle, and Solarius... Solarius flew into the Frostveil Mountains and was never seen again."

Aria sat down heavily on a stool, her legs suddenly unable to support her. "Why didn't you ever tell me?"

"To protect you. After the war, many feared the power of the Dragon Riders. They had saved the kingdoms, yes, but they had also reminded everyone of the terrible destruction dragons could bring. The Riders disbanded, scattered to the winds, hiding their histories. I thought... I hoped the calling would end with your grandfather."

"What do I do now?"

Elara handed her the parchment and the bag. "This is a map. It will lead you to the Eyrie of Dawn, the ancient stronghold of the Dragon Riders. There you will find others who bear the mark, and there you will learn what you need to know. The coins will help you on your journey."

"Journey? Grandmother, I can't just leave! What about the bakery? What about you?"

The old woman smiled, though tears fell freely now. "I managed before you were born, and I'll manage again. As for the bakery, your brother Thomas can help me. This is bigger than bread and coin, child. If the dragons are calling again, it means the world needs them. It means darkness is rising once more."

As if in response to her words, a deep rumble echoed across the village—so low and powerful that it was felt more than heard. The windows rattled, and in the distance, someone screamed. Aria and her grandmother rushed outside to see the entire village gathered in the square, all staring toward the eastern sky.

There, silhouetted against the rising sun, was an unmistakable shape—vast wings beating slowly, a long serpentine neck, a tail that whipped through the air. A dragon, the first seen in the settled lands in half a century, flying toward the mountains.

And in that moment, Aria felt something stir deep within her chest—a yearning, a connection, a call that resonated with the mark on her shoulder. She knew, without understanding how, that this was her destiny approaching. Fear and excitement warred within her, but beneath both was a strange sense of rightness, as if all her life had been leading to this moment.

"When do I leave?" she asked her grandmother, not taking her eyes off the distant dragon.

"Today," Elara replied. "By nightfall, if you can. Others will be traveling to the Eyrie as well. You should try to find companions. The roads are dangerous, especially now."

## Part Two: The Road to the Eyrie

By midday, Aria had packed everything she thought she might need—warm clothes, her grandfather's journal (which her grandmother had also kept in the chest), traveling rations, and the map. She'd said her goodbyes to her younger brother Thomas, who'd looked at her with a mixture of awe and envy when he saw the mark, and to her friends in the village who gathered to see her off.

The village elder, a rotund man named Bartholomew, had pressed a small dagger into her hands. "I'm no warrior," he'd said, "but even I know you can't venture into the wild unarmed. May the Old Gods protect you, Aria Stormwind."

The first three days of travel were uneventful. Aria followed the old King's Road south toward the crossroads at Millhaven, where the map indicated she should turn east toward the Spine Ridge Mountains, where the Eyrie was hidden. She passed merchants heading to market, farmers driving their livestock, and once, a small company of soldiers wearing the blue and silver of the Kingdom of Andor.

Their captain, a scarred woman with keen eyes, had studied Aria carefully as they passed. Aria had kept her shoulder covered, but she felt as though the woman could see the mark anyway. The captain had simply nodded and let her pass without question, though Aria caught her saying something to her lieutenant that sounded like, "Another one. The times are changing."

On the fourth day, Aria met her first fellow traveler bearing the mark.

She'd stopped at a small inn called the Laughing Griffin, planning to spend her second night under a roof before the road became too remote for such comforts. The common room was crowded with travelers escaping a sudden cold rain, and Aria had to share a table with a young man close to her own age.

He was lean and dark-haired, with the sun-bronzed skin of someone who spent most of their time outdoors. His clothes were practical traveling gear, well-made but worn. A bow and quiver rested against the wall beside him, and he moved with the easy confidence of someone comfortable with weapons.

"Mind if I sit?" Aria had asked, and he'd gestured to the empty chair with a smile.

"Company's always welcome on a night like this. I'm Kael Riverwind."

"Aria Stormwind."

His eyebrows rose. "Stormwind? Any relation to Marcus Stormwind, the Dragon Rider?"

Aria's heart skipped. She'd grown so used to keeping her grandfather's history secret that hearing someone speak his name openly felt dangerous. "He was my grandfather. Did you know him?"

"Not personally—I'm not that old," Kael laughed. "But my father served under him during the War of Shadows. Fought in the same campaigns. My father always said Marcus Stormwind was the bravest man he ever knew, and that Solarius was the most magnificent dragon in all the flights."

"Your father was a soldier?"

"A Ranger of the Wildwood. Died three years ago hunting bandits." Kael's expression grew somber. "But he'd told me stories all my life. About the war, the dragons, the Riders. I always half-believed they were just that—stories."

Aria made a decision. Glancing around to ensure no one was paying too much attention to them, she pulled aside her collar just enough to reveal the edge of the dragon mark.

Kael's eyes widened, and then he did something that surprised her—he pulled up his own sleeve to reveal an identical mark, though his was on his forearm rather than his shoulder.

"Appeared four days ago," he said quietly. "I've been traveling south ever since, following a map my father left me. He said if the mark ever appeared, I should go to the Eyrie of Dawn."

"That's where I'm going!" Aria felt a rush of relief. She wasn't alone in this strange new journey. "We could travel together. The roads are dangerous, especially now."

Kael nodded. "I'd be glad of the company. And of someone who understands what this means." He touched his mark, which glowed faintly at his touch, just as Aria's did. "I keep feeling... pulled. Like something is waiting for me. For us."

"The dragons," Aria said.

"Yes. The dragons."

They left together the next morning, and Aria found that traveling with a companion made the journey infinitely more pleasant. Kael was an excellent hunter and tracker, skills he'd learned from his Ranger father, and he taught Aria how to move quietly through the forest, how to read signs of game or danger, and how to shoot the bow he'd given her to practice with.

In return, Aria shared the stories from her grandfather's journal, which chronicled his time as a Rider. They learned of the bond between Rider and dragon—a connection of mind and spirit that went deeper than words, that allowed them to share thoughts and feelings, to fly as one. They read of battles against terrible creatures, of friendships forged in fire, and of the terrible day when Marcus Stormwind had known he would not return from the final confrontation with Malachar.

"He knew," Aria whispered one night as they camped under the stars. "He knew he was going to die, but he went anyway."

"Because it was necessary," Kael said. "Because some things are worth dying for."

"I don't want to die."

"Neither do I. So we'll live. We'll learn, get stronger, and when our time comes, we'll be ready." He smiled at her across the campfire. "Besides, we have each other's backs now."

On the seventh day, they met the third member of their group.

They'd reached the town of Millhaven and were stocking up on supplies before heading into the mountains when they heard a commotion in the market square. A crowd had gathered around a young woman who stood on a wagon, her voice ringing out clearly.

"The dragons return! The old powers awaken! Those who bear the mark, hear me! The time of prophecy is at hand!"

She was striking—tall and graceful, with dark skin and hair that cascaded in locks adorned with silver beads. She wore robes that marked her as a scholar or mage, and in her hand she held a staff topped with a crystal that seemed to glow with inner light.

"Mad, she is," muttered a merchant nearby. "Been going on about dragons all morning."

But Aria felt her mark burning warm beneath her clothes, and when she glanced at Kael, she could see he felt it too. They pushed through the crowd as the town guards arrived to escort the woman down from the wagon.

"Wait!" Aria called out. The woman's eyes found her in the crowd, and they widened with recognition—not of Aria specifically, but of what she was.

"You bear the mark," the woman said, and it wasn't a question.

"As do you, I think," Aria replied.

The woman smiled and pulled aside her robe to reveal a mark on her collarbone, identical in design to Aria's and Kael's. The guards hesitated, looking uncertainly at each other.

"Let her go," Aria said to them. "She's not mad. Everything she says is true."

One of the guards, older than the others, studied all three of them carefully. Then he seemed to come to a decision. "The captain said to watch for young folk with marks, traveling east. Said to let them pass without trouble." He jerked his head at his companions. "Come on. We've got real problems to deal with."

As the guards dispersed, the woman climbed down from the wagon and approached them. "I am Lyra Moonwhisper, scholar of the Arcane Academy of Silverhaven. I have spent five years researching the Dragon Riders and the prophecies surrounding their return. When this mark appeared on me three days ago, I knew my research had become my reality."

"I'm Aria, this is Kael. We're heading to the Eyrie of Dawn."

"As am I. May I join your party? I can offer knowledge and magical protection. I've been studying the old ways, the spells and techniques the Riders used."

Kael looked at Aria, and she saw the question in his eyes. She nodded. "Welcome to the group, Lyra."

That night, in the inn at Millhaven, Lyra spread out scrolls and books on their table, sharing what she'd learned. "The Dragon Riders were formed three thousand years ago," she explained, her finger tracing ancient text. "In the Age of Chaos, when terrible beasts roamed the world and humanity lived in fear, a group of dragons took pity on the mortal races. They offered a bond—their power and longevity combined with human creativity and determination. Together, they brought peace and order to the world."

"But they disbanded after the War of Shadows," Kael said. "Why?"

"Fear," Lyra replied. "The dragons and their Riders had become too powerful. Some kingdoms worried they would become tyrants rather than protectors. And truthfully, there had been dark Riders in the past—those who used their dragons for conquest rather than protection. So when Malachar was defeated, the Riders agreed to scatter. The dragons went to their sleeping places, and the Riders returned to normal lives."

"Then why are the dragons calling again?" Aria asked. "What's changed?"

Lyra's expression grew grave. "There are prophecies, ancient ones, that speak of a Second Darkness—a threat even greater than Malachar, that would rise when the world had forgotten the lessons of the past. The prophecies say that when this darkness comes, the dragons will call forth a new generation of Riders to stand against it."

"What kind of threat?" Kael asked.

"That, I don't know. The prophecies are vague—they speak of shadows rising from the deep places, of old evils awakened, of a winter that won't end. But whatever it is, it's serious enough that the dragons are breaking their long sleep."

A chill ran down Aria's spine. She thought of that dragon she'd seen the morning she received her mark, flying toward the mountains. Had it been going to the Eyrie? Was it there now, waiting for its Rider?

"How many others do you think bear the mark?" she asked.

"The histories say there were fifty Riders at the height of their power," Lyra said. "But that was after centuries of tradition and training. Now? I'd guess perhaps twenty or thirty across all the kingdoms. Enough to form a new flight, if we can all reach the Eyrie."

"Then we'd better get moving," Kael said. "If darkness is coming, we need to be ready."
